We have pictures of this planet approaching the Earth, recorded on cylinder seals. These disasters also create a cycle of civilizations. The Earth's dynamo is general relativistic phenomena.

The Earth is a gravity well like all other planets. Matter within a gravity well stratifies by density with the densest matter (like iron nickle and other ferrous elements) at the core and the light elemental gasses making up the 'atmosphere'

The earth's dynamo being a GR phenomena comes down to time.
If you have 3 identical clocks, one in deep space one at the surface of the earth and one at the center. The clock in deep space will run faster than the clock on the earth's surface where acceleration is 9.8 m/s2
both clocks will run significantly faster than the clock at the center or 'bottom' of the gravity well. (lose the newtonian thinking of a weightless core)

Acceleration as we fall toward a gravity well is fairly well understood. (except for the models that use newtonian physics to talk about what it would be like to fall through a hole in the earth.) the slower the time the greater the acceleration.

This is also true for bodies in rotation or that have spin. The earth rotates on its axis once every 24 hours. But as there is a very large discrepancy between the time at the surface versus time at the bottom of the well (or our core) it causes the core to rotate further for the same amount of observed time than the rotation on the surface.

Yes, our core rotates faster than the surface and it does so in spite of immense friction and all in the vacuum of space. It's what makes our magnetosphere and every magnetosphere in our solar system.

You mixed up the asthenosphere and lithosphere. The lithosphere is solid and the asthenosphere is molten. Tectonic plates (the lithosphere) float on the asthenosphere. Additionally, you are mixing up the physical and chemical characterization of the Earth. Physical characteristics are separated as lithosphere (solid), asthenosphere (liquid), mesosphere (solid but plastic), outer core (liquid), inner core (solid). Chemical characteristics are separated as the crust (mafic to felsic), mantle (ultramafic), and core (Fe-Ni).

I want to preface by saying that I LOVE Kurtzgesagt videos. It's amazing that such high quality content is available freely on the internet.


However, as a geoscientist I noticed a pretty glaring (and perfectly dead wrong) claim in this particular video. At 3:42, you say that the lithosphere is a viscous, convective layer below the crust but the asthenosphere is more solid. This is exactly backwards. The lithosphere (which includes the crust) is brittle and behaves how we typically think of a solid. As you move deeper you hit the brittle-ductile transition where rock no longer breaks in a rigid fashion, but it instead flows and convects. This is the asthenosphere, and the lithosphere "floats" on it.

The Earth's metal core is radioactive  and very hot which keeps the mantle hot ...the mantle is molten liquid rock and iron  .. the circulation of the mantle creates magnetic field ..it creates the Van Allen Radiation belt around the earth.....   part of the mantle that has cooled is called the crust..which is divided into Plate tectonic.. the crust is not a uniform  material .. under the ocean the crust is dense basalt rock ... over land the crust is mainly granite which is lighter than basalt... the tectonic plates that the make up the crust will move over time via earthquakes.. or volcanic action...or bend. deform under massive pressure...The thinnest and denser  section of crust is under the oceans and the thickest and lighter part of the crust is on land....When the earth climate rises and the ice on land melts and the melted ice goes into the ocean ... it shifts the weight of the water from  thicker lighter land plates to the thinner more rigid oceanic plates which bend/deform under the extra weight of the water and put more pressure on the liquid mantle below ....the decrease pressure on the land plates which weight less will put more pressure on the tectonic plate movement via earthquakes and volcanic  action... global warming in theory should increase plate tectonic activity.

NO, we are NOT realy lucky. If universe/earth would have been different we would not be here to ask ourself that question - so by definition we are not lucky because there was no chance for it to be different but still observable. If earth would have been slightly different humans would be different as well - so those "different" humans would call themself lucky to exist too. If earth would have been radically different no human could ever ask himself that question. Its not the earth thats "luckily" made to inhabit humans - humans did evolve to live on earth.

Just imagine rolling 5 dice and waiting for those dice all showing the same number. Its pretty unlucky, right? Imagine a human just pops into existance when you achive that dice roll. Is he going to be suprised to see 5 times the same number on those 5 dice? No. Because thats been the requirement for him to actually pop into existance and notice those dice...

So you could call earth lucky (or not) to have humans - but calling humans lucky to have an earth they can inhabit is just redundand... rather call us "unlucky" because as far as we know earth is the only planet we are ever going to inhabit. So lets call us "unlucky" because there are like 100.000.000.000.000.000.000.000 we are never going to be able to live on because they are either too far away or so deadly you would die in about the time you can hold your breath... So if you call us lucky to be able to live on earth you as well have to call us unlucky for not being able to live on Mars. And Jupiter. And Saturn. And Venus. And Mercury. Fun fact: The Sun is often described as an 'average' or 'small' star, but in fact this is not the case. The sun is quite a large star, being more luminous, massive and taking up more volume than 90% of stars in the Milky Way. Most stars in the Milky Way are cool and dim red dwarfs. The closest extrasolar star to us is Proxima Centauri, which is a red dwarf. It is so dim that it is not visible to the naked eye, and it is only 4.25 light years away. 80% of stars are red dwarfs, with most being a similar size and mass to Proxima Centauri. Most of the rest are orange dwarfs, stars with 45 to 80% of the mass of the sun, and having a cooler temperature (usually within 4000-5000k, compared to the Sun's 5500k). The last one or two percent are smaller yellow dwarfs. The reason you don't see these more often is simply because they are too dim to be seen in the night sky, red dwarfs from any distance and orange dwarfs from a few parsecs away. We just see more of the top few percent largest and brightest stars in the night sky because they are bright enough to be seen from hundreds or even thousands of light years away.

In conclusion, yes, there are stars much bigger and brighter than the sun, but the sun is quite a large star itself, and is bigger and brighter than most stars in the Milky Way and probably the Universe.

I think you're confusing the properties of the lithosphere and asthenosphere. The lithosphere is not viscous. It's a rigid, rocky (litho = rock) layer, which includes the crust and the solid outermost part of the mantle. It's this lithosphere which is broken up into the plates that shift around.

It's the asthenosphere that is more plastic, and is able to flow. This more viscous layer allows the plates above to slide around. The terms "crust" and "mantle" are distinguished by differences in composition, whereas the lithosphere and asthenosphere differ in their physical properties.

I am 1:10, and would just like to point out that it is extremely unlikely that the moon was formed that way. underneath the surface of the moon, there is actually a fair amount of moisture. This would be impossible if the moon had come off the earth in many tiny pieces which eventually turned into the moon we know today. The likely way it would have as much moisture as it does today is if it came to be all in one piece. We also know that the moon is made of the same rock as the earth's mantle. One thing that I am curious about is how do we know that the Earth is made up like this? We tend to state it as fact, but as noted in the video we've only dug down about 7 miles which is no where near the next layer. So how is it that we know what the Earth is made up of? Educated guesses? Assumptions based on mathematical models? I'm not a naysayer, I'm literally just curious about how we came up with that.

How could you show Thea colliding head-on with Earth? This would not throw anything into any kind of orbit at all! A critical factor for our planet is that Thea hit us at a very shallow angle, breaking it up, and causing almost the entire iron core from the impactor to be retained by the Earth, while the resulting Moon ended up with a tiny iron core.

Without the MASSIVE iron core of Earth, our magnetic field would not be strong enough, and would not survive long enough to allow anything more than single celled organisms to evolve.

Ignoring this was a huge mistake.

Geologist here (M.S. 2016, focus: Igneous Petrology) The lithosphere is rigid, does not flow, and acts as a keel to the tectonic plates while the asthenosphere flows quite a bit (it's what moves the plates, including the rigid lithosphere keels). And both are solid.

(Yes, a solid that flows: olivine becomes ductile at high enough temperatures- the boundary where this temperature is reached defines the transition from the lithosphere and the asthenosphere).

Litho- = stone = hard
astheno- = Greek astheneia, "weakness" = flows

Didn't catch any other errors.

He got the lithosphere and asthenosphere wrong. Lithosphere is hard and rigid and moves along with the crust (actually, technically, it CONSISTS of the crust, and the topmost ~100km of the upper mantle). Asthenosphere is soft and flowy but it's still a solid (a very viscous solid). The lithosphere slides above the asthenosphere to create plate tectonics.

Hi, I want to correct your video on one comment: the lithosphere is actually the rigid solid part of our earth that made up of the crust and uppermost mantle.  The upper mantle below this and the lower mantle make up the asthenosphere which is also "solid", but convective, and less viscous. The reason this solid can convect is because the deeper into the earth, the hotter, the weaker the silicate rock crystalline bonds, the more slippage between the bonds. This results in very slow convection. The melts we see in the lithosphere are all very much localized and due to either upwelling asthenosphere, or due to dewatering of minerals at subduction zones.

so... Asthenosphere... In the wrong place. The uppermost level of the mantle (labeled the lithosphere) is liquid and called the asthenosphere. Above it is the crust, and below it is the solid part of the upper mantle (labeled the asthenosphere), together these two layers are the lithosphere. The crust is solid because it is not hot enough. Water in the asthenosphere acts as a flux, allowing it to melt at a much lower temperature than it should. The pressure in the lower lithosphere helps to overcome the fluxing effect of water, and forces water out of the rock. These two effects allow the lower lithosphere to stay solid even though it is much hotter than the asthenosphere.

Umm three things.

One we know believe that Sol our sun formed absurdly close to another star (not Nemesis, were never a binary just ultra close stellar formation) that as it and the sun started going its separate ways started pulling the solar systems center of mass (and the biggest planets) away from the sun stretching out the solar system into its current form.

Also plate tectonics is also believed to be combination of two factors you left out, energy left over from the creation of the moon and water still trapped in upper and lower mantel. But the discovery of so much water in the mantel is relatively new.

Finally, the most accepted theory about why the Earth's core is a magnetic dynamo is from a combination of factors. One it is twice as massive as the other rock planet cores, since it is made for original Earths core and the planet the collided with us. Second, the heat at the core should force it to be liquid or even gaseous, but the pressure of the outer core and mantel is forcing it to remain solid. Its believed that its this pressure and it being prevented from phase changing is providing energy to keep its temperature so high and for its dynamo effect. By careful study of previous magnetic pole flips, we found that this dynamo effect reaches its peak and eventually grows weaker and weaker until the magnet field collapse (in an average of 100,000 year time frame), until in what could be as little as 12 hours the magnet poles flip and grow in strength but again as intense this new flip poles field strength is. It also suddenly weakens disappears (again over the course of hours) and the poles flip getting stronger and stronger again to point when the beginning to weaken to start the process all over again.

I just want to point out that the idea that planets are formed in a slow process by the clumping together of dust particles from stellar accretion discs is a theoretical process which has not been proven, nor has it ever been directly observed, yet it is stated as fact in the video. This is a detail worth mentioning in educational material.

Recent exoplanet discoveries (e.g. a super massive gas giant orbiting within "a hair's breadth" in astronomical terms of its parent star; also rogue planets orbiting over twice the distance away from their parent stars as Pluto is from our Sun; and many other "surprising" discoveries) have led mainstream astronomers to question the validity of the long-standing accretion disc model. In fact, some of these astronomers (including NASA scientists) have suggested that the accretion model of planetary formation is simply obsolete, and that a new model will have to be developed from scratch.

It just so happens that a comprehensive and scientifically sound alternative already exists, backed by a Nobel-winning physicist and many other accredited scientists, from fields of study ranging from biology and ancient mythology, to plasma physics and electrical engineering. Unfortunately, there are significant obstacles standing in the way of even valid and scientifically sound theories being accepted into the mainstream. New observations, findings, and discoveries (especially those which are said to have "baffled" and "surprised" establishment scientists) tend to result in eruptions of controversy and contention in the scientific community (a well-known example being the initial response to Galileo's discovery that the Sun does not revolve around the Earth). Though the response to Galileo's discovery is an extreme case, it is by no means exceptional. Some segments of our modern-day scientific community have earned themselves a reputation for clinging to their long-held theories like priests to religious dogma. We're talking about much more than stellar accretion discs. There are a great deal of inconsistencies and outright falsehoods throughout the body of "settled" science. Within the various fields of astrophysics there are falsehoods built upon falsehoods, which have come to be accepted as natural law; the complex interconnectedness of this web makes it virtually impossible to revise or alter a given theoretical model without creating a cascade of logical fallacies that ripple into other models, effectively invalidating the entire construct.

The natural world is similarly an infinitely complex array of interdependencies, but in nature, things are not this fragile.

When science is no longer about exploring the unknown and unmasking the mysterious.. when appearing "correct" is valued above a willingness to be proven wrong and admit to error.. when the defense, maintenance, and preservation of a widely accepted lie is more important than being open to new ideas.. then it's no longer science.

Over the past couple years, we've been seeing a continuous string of press releases announcing, more or less, "Scientists baffled by new discovery A" and "New observations contradict everything we thought we knew about B". This, in my humble opinion, is a sign that astrophysicists are just beginning to wake up to the realization that they've been ignoring a crucial piece of the astrophysical puzzle, even though it's been staring them in the face the entire time. In the coming months and years, look for this trend in science news to continue as it segues into admissions of error, but also releases detailing new theoretical models set to replace old ones.

If you read the above novella, thanks for your time and open mind.
